definitions: prepare or flavor food with a spicy sauce made from various aromatic spices
clean and brush an animal's coat with a special comb to remove dirt
examples: She learned to curry vegetables with authentic Indian spices
The chef curries chicken every Friday for lunch special
The stable hand curries the horses every morning carefully
You should curry your horse after each riding session

definitions: use offensive or blasphemous language to express anger or frustration
call upon supernatural powers to bring harm or misfortune to someone
cause persistent trouble or suffering to affect someone or something negatively
examples: He cursed loudly when he stubbed his toe badly
The angry driver cursed at the traffic jam endlessly
The witch cursed the prince to sleep for eternity
Ancient sailors believed Neptune could curse their voyages dangerously
Bad weather has cursed our vacation plans this year
The team seems cursed with injuries throughout the season

definitions: reduce the extent, quantity, or duration of something by imposing limits or removing parts
examples: The company had to curtail spending during the recession
New regulations curtail the use of plastic bags significantly

definitions: cover or conceal something using a curtain or similar hanging fabric barrier
bring a theatrical performance or act to its conclusion or final moment
examples: Heavy fabric curtains the window from the morning sunlight
They curtained off the construction area for safety reasons
The director decided to curtain the scene with dramatic music
The play curtains at exactly ten o'clock every evening

definitions: bend or cause something to bend in a smooth continuous arc without angles
move or cause to move along a path that deviates from straight
examples: The artist curves the metal into an elegant sculpture
The river curves around the mountain base naturally
The ball curved left just before reaching the goal
The road curves sharply through the mountain pass ahead

definitions: reduce the force or shock of an impact using soft material or buffer
protect someone or something from harmful effects or unpleasant consequences through preventive measures
examples: The airbag cushions the driver during a collision impact
Thick carpet cushions your feet on the hard floor
Government subsidies cushion farmers from market price fluctuations
Her savings account cushions her against unexpected expenses

definitions: modify or build something according to individual requirements or personal preferences and specifications
examples: The company can customize software to meet your business needs
She customized her motorcycle with unique paint and chrome parts

definitions: divide or separate something using a sharp tool or blade
reduce the size, amount, or duration of something significantly
stop or interrupt something suddenly and completely
move directly across rather than around something to save time
examples: She carefully cut the fabric with sharp scissors
The surgeon cuts precisely along the marked incision line
The company decided to cut costs by twenty percent
Congress voted to cut funding for the program significantly
The director cut the scene from the final movie version
The storm cut power to thousands of homes overnight
We can cut through the park to save time
The boat cuts through the waves at high speed

definitions: ride a bicycle or similar pedal-powered vehicle for transportation or exercise
move through a repeating series of events or stages in order
put something through a complete process or system of operations
examples: She cycles to work every morning for exercise
The children love to cycle in the park together
The seasons cycle through spring summer autumn and winter
Economic patterns tend to cycle between growth and recession
The washing machine cycles through wash rinse and spin
The air conditioner cycles on and off automatically

definitions: convert a message into secret code using a systematic method of encryption
perform mathematical calculations or work out numerical problems through computation
examples: Intelligence agents cypher messages before transmitting classified information
The spy had to cypher the document using complex algorithms
Students must cypher these equations to find the correct answer
Accountants cypher the quarterly reports for accuracy and compliance

definitions: press something lightly and briefly against a surface without rubbing
apply a small amount of substance with light quick touches
examples: She dabbed her eyes with a tissue during the movie
The nurse dabs the wound with antiseptic before bandaging
He dabs cologne on his neck every morning
The artist dabs paint onto the canvas creating texture

definitions: act slowly or waste time by being indecisive or doing unimportant things
behave in a playful or flirtatious manner without serious intentions
examples: Don't dally on your way home from school today
He dallied too long and missed the important meeting
She liked to dally with her admirers at parties
The young couple dallied in the garden all afternoon

definitions: build a barrier across a river or stream to control water flow
obstruct or hold back the flow or progress of something
examples: Beavers dam the stream with branches and mud naturally
Engineers will dam the river to create a reservoir
Bureaucracy often dams the flow of innovative ideas
Fallen trees dammed the road after the storm

definitions: cause physical harm or injury that impairs value, usefulness, or normal function
cause harm to someone's reputation, prospects, or abstract qualities
examples: The storm damaged hundreds of homes along the coast
Rough handling can damage delicate electronic equipment easily
The scandal seriously damaged his political career permanently
False rumors can damage a company's reputation severely

definitions: condemn or criticize something or someone very strongly and harshly
condemn someone to eternal punishment in hell according to religious belief
examples: Critics damn the new policy as completely ineffective
The judge damned their behavior as utterly irresponsible
Medieval priests claimed they could damn souls to hell
Some religions believe God damns unrepentant sinners eternally

definitions: make something slightly wet or moist without soaking it completely
reduce the intensity, vigor, or amplitude of something gradually
examples: Morning dew damps the grass before sunrise every day
She damps the cloth before ironing the delicate fabric
The padding damps the sound from the neighboring apartment
Rain tends to damp everyone's enthusiasm for outdoor activities

definitions: make something slightly wet or humid by adding moisture gradually
make feelings, reactions, or activities less intense or enthusiastic
examples: The gardener dampens the soil before planting new seeds
Fog dampens everything in the early morning hours
Bad weather dampened our spirits during the camping trip
High prices dampen consumer demand for luxury goods

definitions: move the body rhythmically to music, typically following set sequences of steps
move quickly and lightly in a lively or excited way
examples: They danced together at their wedding reception all night
Children love to dance when they hear upbeat music
Sunlight dances on the water creating beautiful patterns
The boxer danced around his opponent avoiding every punch

definitions: have the courage or boldness to do something difficult or dangerous
challenge someone to do something requiring courage as a test
examples: She didn't dare speak during the important board meeting
Few people dare to climb that dangerous mountain peak
His friends dared him to jump into the lake
I dare you to eat that super spicy pepper

definitions: make or become dark or darker by reducing light or adding shadow
make or become unhappy, angry, or threatening in mood or atmosphere
examples: Storm clouds darken the sky before the rain arrives
She darkened the room by closing all the curtains
His expression darkened when he heard the bad news
The political situation continues to darken throughout the region

definitions: mend a hole in fabric by weaving thread across it systematically
express mild annoyance or frustration as a gentle substitute for stronger language
examples: My grandmother taught me to darn socks properly
She darns the worn areas of her favorite sweater
Darn it I forgot my keys again today
Well darn that didn't work as we planned

definitions: move suddenly and rapidly in a particular direction with quick motion
throw or propel something quickly and accurately at a target
examples: The rabbit darted across the path into the bushes
Her eyes darted nervously around the crowded room
He darted the paper airplane across the classroom
The frog's tongue darts out to catch flying insects

definitions: run or move very quickly for a short distance with sudden speed
destroy or frustrate hopes, plans, or expectations completely and suddenly
throw or strike something with great force against a surface
examples: She dashed to catch the bus before it left
The children dash around the playground during recess
The rain dashed our hopes for a beach picnic
One mistake can dash years of careful planning
Waves dash against the rocks during the storm
He dashed the glass against the wall in anger

definitions: establish or ascertain the date or age of an object or event
go out socially with someone in whom one has a romantic interest
show signs of being old-fashioned or become out of style
examples: Scientists date the fossil to the Jurassic period
Experts can date paintings by analyzing the paint composition
They started dating after meeting at the conference
He's dating someone from his photography class now
That hairstyle really dates you to the eighties
Some comedy shows date quickly and lose their relevance

definitions: coat or smear a surface with a thick or sticky substance carelessly
paint something in a crude, unskilled, or hurried manner
examples: Children daub finger paint all over the paper enthusiastically
Workers daub plaster on the walls before smoothing
Street artists daub graffiti on abandoned building walls
He daubed bright colors on the canvas without planning

definitions: begin to become visible or apparent as light appears in the sky
begin to be perceived or understood by someone gradually
examples: Day dawns earlier in summer than in winter months
A new era dawns for the technology industry
The truth finally dawned on her after the meeting
It dawned on me that I was completely wrong

definitions: indulge in pleasant fantasies or thoughts while awake, typically losing awareness of surroundings
examples: Students often daydream during long boring lectures
She daydreams about traveling to exotic places someday

definitions: make someone unable to think or react properly by stunning or bewildering them
examples: The blow to his head dazed him for several minutes
Bright lights and loud music dazed the concert audience

definitions: blind temporarily with bright light or brilliant reflections that overwhelm vision
greatly impress someone with outstanding skill, beauty, or magnificent display
examples: The sun dazzles drivers on the highway during sunset
Stage lights dazzle performers when they first walk out
Her performance dazzled the judges and earned first place
The magician dazzles audiences with incredible illusions nightly

definitions: make something inactive or inoperative by disconnecting or disabling its operating mechanism
examples: Please deactivate the alarm before entering the building
The company will deactivate unused accounts after six months

definitions: distribute playing cards to players in a game according to rules
take action to handle or cope with a person, problem, or situation
buy and sell particular goods as a commercial business activity
examples: She deals five cards to each player clockwise
It's your turn to deal the next hand
Teachers must deal with difficult students every day
The manager deals with customer complaints professionally
He deals in antique furniture and vintage collectibles
That company deals exclusively in organic food products

definitions: officially exclude or prohibit someone from doing something or entering somewhere
examples: The court debarred him from practicing law for five years
Students who cheat are debarred from taking future exams

definitions: argue about a subject in a formal manner presenting different viewpoints
think about something carefully by considering different possibilities before deciding
examples: Politicians debate healthcare reform in congress every session
Students debate current issues in their civics class weekly
She debated whether to accept the job offer overnight
The committee debates each proposal before making decisions

definitions: remove money from a bank account or charge to an account
record an amount as a debit in financial accounting records
examples: The bank debits your account for each transaction fee
The store will debit your credit card immediately
Accountants debit expenses and credit revenues in ledgers
You must debit this amount in the proper column

definitions: identify and remove errors from computer software or hardware systems
search for and remove hidden listening devices or surveillance equipment
examples: Programmers debug code before releasing software to users
It takes hours to debug complex applications thoroughly
Security teams debug the conference room before important meetings
They had to debug the embassy after discovering surveillance

definitions: expose the falseness or hollowness of a myth, idea, or belief publicly
examples: Scientists debunk conspiracy theories with factual evidence regularly
The investigation debunked claims of widespread voter fraud

definitions: perform in public or appear formally for the first time professionally
examples: The actress will debut on Broadway next month
The new product debuts at the technology conference tomorrow

definitions: rot or decompose through natural biological or chemical processes over time
gradually decline in quality, power, or vigor over an extended period
examples: Dead leaves decay into rich soil over several months
Sugar causes teeth to decay without proper dental care
The abandoned building continues to decay year after year
Their relationship began to decay after constant arguments

definitions: deliberately cause someone to believe something false through lies or trickery
examples: The con artist deceived elderly victims out of their savings
Don't let appearances deceive you into making assumptions

definitions: make a choice or judgment after considering various possibilities carefully
determine or settle an issue or contest with finality
examples: She decided to pursue graduate studies in medicine
The committee will decide on funding allocations tomorrow
The final goal decided the championship match dramatically
One vote could decide the entire election outcome

definitions: convert coded or unclear writing into normal language through analysis
succeed in understanding something that is unclear or difficult to interpret
examples: Archaeologists decipher ancient hieroglyphics using linguistic patterns
Cryptographers work to decipher enemy communications during wartime
I can't decipher his handwriting without my reading glasses
Scientists struggle to decipher the meaning of these results

definitions: decorate or adorn something with ribbons, flowers, or other ornamental items
knock someone to the ground with a powerful punch or blow
examples: They deck the halls with holly every Christmas season
The wedding planner decked the venue with white roses
The boxer decked his opponent in the third round
One punch decked the troublemaker at the bar

definitions: make a formal or official statement or announcement about something important
report goods or income to customs or tax authorities as required
examples: The president declared a state of emergency yesterday
The company declared bankruptcy after years of losses
Travelers must declare items over the duty-free limit
You need to declare all foreign income on taxes

definitions: politely refuse an invitation, offer, or request
decrease gradually in size, amount, intensity, or importance
gradually deteriorate in strength, quality, or condition over time
examples: She declined the job offer to stay with family
He politely declined their invitation to dinner tonight
Sales declined steadily throughout the economic recession period
Student enrollment has declined for three consecutive years
His health began to decline after the accident
The empire slowly declined over several centuries

definitions: convert a coded message into intelligible language using a key or system
examples: The software decodes encrypted files using advanced algorithms
Radio operators decode morse code messages during emergencies

definitions: officially withdraw something from active service, especially military equipment or nuclear facilities
examples: The navy will decommission three submarines this year
They plan to decommission the nuclear plant by twenty-thirty

definitions: break down into simpler substances through natural biological or chemical processes
break something down into its constituent parts for analysis or understanding
examples: Organic matter decomposes faster in warm humid conditions
The body had decomposed beyond recognition unfortunately
Scientists decompose compounds to study their molecular structure
We can decompose this problem into smaller manageable tasks

definitions: analyze a text or linguistic phenomenon to expose its hidden assumptions
take something apart in order to understand its components or structure
examples: Literary critics deconstruct novels to reveal underlying meanings
The professor deconstructs gender stereotypes in advertising
Engineers deconstruct the device to understand its mechanism
Chefs deconstruct traditional recipes into modern presentations

definitions: make something more attractive by adding ornamental items or color
award a medal or honor to someone for distinguished service or achievement
examples: They decorate their house with lights every holiday season
The interior designer decorated the office beautifully
The military decorated the soldier for exceptional bravery
The queen decorated several citizens for community service

definitions: lure or entice a person or animal away from their intended course
examples: Hunters use calls to decoy ducks into shooting range
The thieves decoyed the guard away from his post
